thread.title: No word on Rasheed Wallace, Tayshaun Prince jersey retirement - yet
thread.title_full: No word on Rasheed Wallace, Tayshaun Prince jersey retirement - yet

author: freep.com
title: No word on Rasheed Wallace, Tayshaun Prince jersey retirement - yet
text:
MORE Best five alive.
That’s what each member of the Detroit Pistons’ vaunted starting five that won the 2004 NBA title would remind each other before games during their run of dominance.
Of that starting five, Rip Hamilton joined Ben Wallace and Chauncey Billups in having jersey numbers retired by the franchise on Sunday at the Palace.
Will the last two – Rasheed Wallace and Tayshaun Prince – come soon?
The official word is the franchise is so preoccupied with the move to play in Little Caesars Arena next season that the matter really hasn’t been discussed yet.
“No decision has been made yet,” Palace Sports & Entertainment vice chairman Arn Tellem told the Free Press in December.
“Right now, we’re going to focus our attention on Rip. Nothing is planned at this point.”
But on a night when all five members were in the house to remember an excellent era of Pistons basketball, Hamilton gave a hearty endorsement.
“Our motto was we’re the best five alive before every game,” Hamilton said before his jersey retirement ceremony. "That was our chant in the middle of the huddle, best five alive.”
“We all knew that in order for us to be great at what we do, we needed each other. We needed our brothers.”
Rasheed Wallace. (Photo: Paul Sancya, Associated Press)
When then-Pistons president Joe Dumars pulled off the 2004 trade deadline deal for Wallace, it was the move that made a good team a great team.
Pistons coach Stan Van Gundy had to deal with Rasheed Wallace in coaching stints with the Miami Heat and Orlando Magic.
“To me, that move was what made them great,” Van Gundy said before the Pistons faced the Celtics Sunday. “He’s one of the more underrated guys. He was an elite-level defender, could guard on the perimeter and in the post, could shoot the ball from three and score in the post, and was a good passer.
“In a lot of ways, he was the linchpin in that whole thing. But he hadn’t been here as long, so I don’t think he has ever gotten the recognition that those other guys have gotten. Even though people like him here, he maybe did not get the same adoration from the fans the other guys have gotten.”
Hamilton had even more praise for Wallace.
“I tell people this all the time, Rasheed Wallace is the most talented player I ever played with in the NBA, but he was willing to sacrifice in order for his brothers to get some the glory, too,” Hamilton said.
Prince was the Pistons’ first-round pick in 2002. He was the fifth option once Wallace arrived, Hamilton said his sacrifice was needed. He said Prince could have been a leading scorer on another team.
Contact Vince Ellis at vellis@freepress.com . Follow him on Twitter @vincent_ellis56 .
